Isolate several tadpolcs in separate drops of water in watch
glasses, for study of behavior during attachment. Cover them, and
make observations several times during the next two days. The
metamorphosis to the simple ascidian form takes place within a few
hours after attachment, but the results can be observed best from
two days to a week later.

Observe specimens of metamorphosing
cimm larvae that have been growing for a

water. In handling them, be sure not to

nor tip off their cover of water. Debris may be gently flushed
off them at the tap. Examine them under
the microscope first with
low power, for orientation. After making your records, return
specimens, still living in dieir watch glasses, to the frames they
came from.
The post-abdominal region with the heart at its tip is the
first thing noticed. Watch the heart for unusual behavior. Find
the atrial and oral siphons. The pharynx with itshnumerous stigmata
opens into a short esophagus which connects with a round yellow
stomach marked by muscular bands.
The intestine tunns sharply after leaving the stomach, and
ends near the atrial siphon. The endostyle is sharply indicated
on the wall of the pharynx, delimiting the two atrial pouches. These
pouches surround the pharynx and open to
siphon. Note the structure of the mouth
